references: which we can see is simply a relabeling of the inequality in (26) and, thus, can be traced back to the CHSH inequality for the Bell test where a#superscript#a^{\#}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an input for bbitalic_b and, b#superscript#b^{\#}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as an input for ccitalic_c. Therefore, the conditions (105), (109), and (110) must be satisfied in order to claim a non-classicality from data fusion in the 3-way synthesis. For quantum distributions, however, the only relevant inequality will be (110) and its relabelings. The final step of the proof consists of showing the incompatibility of the three data tables with a joint classical model and its covered in the main text. .

This shows that the DAG 8a1 supports non-classicality from data fusion considering only interventions on AAitalic_A.

We needed to appeal to a quantum strategy that uses 3 effective inputs as the binary case does not lead to non-classical
Instrumental correlations. This might suggest, naively,
that violation of Bonets inequality (38) uncovers
a stronger form of non-locality, requiring violating
beyond the CHSH inequality. It has been shown in [45] that this is not the case. In particular, we can see the Bonet inequalities are particular liftings of the CHSH inequality and, as a consequence of this relationship, any non-classical correlation in the CHSH Bell scenario can be used as a resource to generate non-classical correlations violating the Bonet inequality.

Therefore, non-classicality from data fusion in the UC scenario is a necessary condition for non-classicality in Fig. 12a1. If we do this for the inequality (48) we will obtain a classically valid causal inequality for the scenario in Fig. 12a1 and we can recycle the same violation from before using the strategy outlined in Theorem 1, with the minor difference that now CCitalic_C outputs the bit from \alphaitalic_ regardless of bbitalic_b and aaitalic_a. The non-classicality of noisy strategies can also be certified in a similar way to what was done for the Evans scenario in Appendix A. The corresponding inequality for this relaxation of the Evans UC scenario is shown in  [1].

Subsequently, we can pullback this inequality in terms of the observational and interventional data tables of the scenario using the relationship in (LABEL:eq:relation_Q_to_P_extra_edge_Evans) to obtain

We remark that inequality (63) is an instance of Sliwas 46 tripartite Bell inequalities [49]; namely, it is a relabelling of Sliwa class #4#4\#4# 4. Remarkably, inequality (63) and its relabelling are necessary and sufficient to witness non-classicality in the 3-way synthesis for data tables where all variables are binary and all 2-way syntheses are classical, and it admits quantum violation.

which we can see is simply a relabeling of the inequality in (26) and, thus, can be traced back to the CHSH inequality for the Bell test where a#superscript#a^{\#}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an input for bbitalic_b and, b#superscript#b^{\#}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as an input for ccitalic_c. The final step of the proof consists of showing the incompatibility of the three data tables with a joint classical model and its covered in the main text. .

Similarly to what was done in Appendix A, we can modify the quadratic program (115) introducing a quantity qsubscript\mathcal{M}_{q}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined as

We can recycle the coarse-grained Fritz model to achieve quantum non-classicality from data fusion in the triangle scenario with two additional arrows coming from AAitalic_A with a fork-like structure, shown in Fig. (19b1). Similarly to the case of only one additional arrow, we can identify QABC|A#(a,b,c|a#=0)subscriptconditionalsuperscript#conditionalsuperscript#0Q_{ABC|A^{\#}}(a,b,c|a^{\#}=0)italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A italic_B italic_C | italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a , italic_b , italic_c | italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 ) with the Fritz model and pullback the original inequality derived by the inflation technique. The proof of classical compatibility of the individual data tables follows from the same arguments given in Lemma 1, using the H.L.P. conditions in the corresponding graphs for PABCsubscriptP_{ABC}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A italic_B italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and PBC|do(A)subscriptconditionalP_{BC|do(A)}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B italic_C | italic_d italic_o ( italic_A ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This yields the same symbolic bound given in (125). Note that, although we had already shown the validity of the inequality (125), our arguments show that this inequality is still valid for the more permissive case with the extra edge ACA\rightarrow Citalic_A  italic_C.
